channel.title: Memleak
channel.description: This is not exactly a hard question, but can someone please explain to me as a noob what a memory leak is?

item.title: Memleak
item.dc:creator: @No_Life2 No Life
item.description:
@No_Life2 wrote:

Davidi2:

Constantly creating objects that aren’t being used, but for some reason aren’t being collected as garbage.

I hope you’re talking about JAVA objects such as: String temp = new String(“someValue”);

And not WORLD objects such as: createObject(objectID, X, Y, Z);

Because memory leaks in java, basically is shitty programming. It happens when someone doesn’t know how to use the high-end java libraries such as Threads. (e.g. They don’t know when to stop/start a thread, therefore it remains on forever, collecting memory from your computer, and eventually lagging the entire server).

That’s BASICALLY what java memory leaks are. Not exactly…

Read full topic

I understand that (lol) but I wasn’t sure exactly what a leak of memory was.

item.title: Memleak
item.dc:creator: @krackkid Krackkid
item.description:
@krackkid wrote:

[quote=“Mill, post:1, topic:400914”]This is not exactly a hard question, but can someone please explain to me as a noob what a memory leak is?[/quote]A Leak of memory.

en.wikipedia.org

Memory leak

In computer science, a memory leak is a type of resource leak that occurs when a computer program incorrectly manages memory allocations in such a way that memory which is no longer needed is not released. In object-oriented programming, a memory leak may happen when an object is stored in memory but cannot be accessed by the running code. A memory leak has symptoms similar to a number of other problems and generally can only be diagnosed by a programmer with access to the program's source A spa...

Read full topic
